title: Du'a al-Sabah
text:
Du'a al-Sabah () (literally the supplication of Sabah, "orison of the morning") is a prayer advised by the first <a href="Imam">Imam</a> of the <a href="Shia%20Islam">Shiites</a>, <a href="Ali%20ibn%20Abi%20Talib">Ali ibn Abi Talib</a>, to be recited in the morning. This prayer was written on the 28th of September in the year 646 (11th of <a href="Dhu%20al-Hijjah">Dhu al-Hijjah</a> in the year 25 <a href="Hijri%20year">AH</a>) by <a href="Ali%20ibn%20Abi%20Talib">Ali ibn Abi Talib</a>, learned from <a href="Muhammad">Muhammad ibn Abdullah</a>, the Prophet of <a href="Islam">Islam</a>. "Du'a al-Sabah" is mentioned by <a href="Mohammad-Baqer%20Majlesi">Mohammad-Baqer Majlesi</a> in his books <a href="Bihar%20al-Anwar">Bihar al-Anwar</a> and "Salah". In a treatise by "Yahya ibn Qasim Alavi (seventh century AH)", it is claimed that a copy of this prayer was written in <a href="Kufic%20script">Kufic script</a> by <a href="Ali%20ibn%20Abi%20Talib">Imam Ali</a> himself. The oldest authentication related to the "Du'a al-Sabah" is the book ""Ikhtiar al-Misbah" written by "Sayyid Ali ibn al-Husayn ibn Hessan ibn al-Baqi al-Qurashi"" in 1255 (653 AH).
This prayer is also known as the "Du'a al-Sabah of <a href="Amir%20al-Mu%27minin">Amir al-Mu'minin</a>", and most of the material contained in this prayer, is consistent with the teachings of "<a href="Quran">Quran</a> and Islamic narrations" and has been mentioned in other prayers. <a href="Mohammad-Baqer%20Majlesi">Mohammad-Baqer Majlesi</a> advised to recite this prayer after the <a href="Dawn%20prayer">dawn</a> <a href="salah">salah</a>; "Sayyid ibn Baqi" also recommends reciting it after the <a href="Dawn%20prayer">dawn</a> <a href="supererogatory%20prayer">supererogatory</a> <a href="salah">salah</a>.
